metadata.name: Conversations Are Valuable 1
metadata.description:
If great ideas are valuable [1], then shouldn't the great conversations that generate those ideas be valuable as well? 

What would the world look like if we established norms around digital attribution for ideas and conversations so that if my idea was inspired by a conversation I can pay homage and direct value/attention back to the conversation? Or if my conversation was inspired by an idea I can pay homage and direct value/attention back to the idea? And what if the records that contain these ideas and conversations can become valuable artifacts of our digital history?

While we're fairly used to text citations and linking to blog posts, Twitter threads, etc., the reality is that not all great ideas are captured in writing. And even if you did transcribe those ideas word for word the transcription process is lossy. You can capture the words, but you likely cannot capture the full details of the moment in which the idea was presented including voice intonation, visible excitement, facial expressions, body language, accompanying media to help visualize the idea. 

As a society, we seem to be increasingly capturing more of our great ideas and conversations in video and audio form (at least the ones that are intended for public consumption). If we start to create records that contain not only these ideas, but also conversations with clear provenance linking to the audiovisual moments around these ideas such that value and attention can flow through the provenance chain maybe we end up with building blocks for even greater ideas and even greater conversations.

[1] https://zora.co/collections/0x62d946854628e8e7f6fa4ee219f1f54642f08a94
